teach.question: structure
teach.raw_text: Structural racism is a continuous cycle that has historically hurt the minorities in the United States. The cycle must be broken, and to achieve this we must start at the very bottom and work our way up. This change will take a lot of time, but is the only foreseeable way to ensure the cycle is completely broken. We can start at the education level by ensuring education centers in poor minority areas are modernized and teach a well-rounded curriculum that inspires young students to grow into the person they wish to be. To ensure education remains a top priority at these schools we can implement types of positions that ensure the safety of education atmospheres and denounce crime related activity. Once the education level plan is intact it must be monitored and consistently altered to fit the active world's society and top understanding. After this we may move onto aid. Aid must be given out to those who absolutely need it. In the aid we should implement growth incentives to ensure that the people who are receiving aid are growing and putting themselves into valuable positions in society that not only hold value to them, but society as a whole. This incentive aid will break the generational cycle of families who rely on federal aid.

teach.raw_text: To combat the issue of structural racism in policing and in America as a whole, would be to hold the police and various other organizations that may unequally treat Black Americans (Insurance market possibly) more accountable for their actions. For policing specifically, there needs to be the abolishment of severe revamps in the idea of qualified immunity - the ability for police officers to act unlawful in an event that is "out-of-line". While it is valuable if the police officer was threatened by a gun, most Black Americans are subjected to aggressive force used by the police such as in the case of George Floyd. Removing the immunity would hold the police and the departments liable for any acts that can be considered discriminatory and over the top. While this does not stop the racial bias in PredPol or the policies' discriminatory behavior, it would hold them accountable which to some extent, may help aid in the creation of less structural racism.  To combat the historical aspect of racism, there should be some form of racial bias education sessions mandated by all elementary schools and taught throughout the K-12 system. In hopes to maintain a community that does not actively have racial bias in the workforce, the training sessions should also exist in the workforce.

impact.question: history
impact.raw_text: To address the fact that "American society has been historically unequal and discriminatory, and structural racism is reproduced over time"? you must acknowledge the current flaws in the policing system. For example, black males in America are more than 5 times as likely than white males in Americans to say they have been unjustifiably stopped by the police. This is concrete evidence that black males in America are at a disadvantage with the police who are supposed to protect us.  You can't change the fact that "American society has been historically unequal and discriminatory, and structural racism is reproduced over time," but in addressing the situation in order to provide a solution we could try to encourage inclusion of all communities. In the video, "Does My Neighborhood Determine My Future," Professor Jacob Faber explains how segregation during the 20th century has prevented people of color, especially African-Americans, from many opportunities that would have improved their lives. Even though segregation is banned now however, its effects still linger within a lot of neighborhoods and impact the level of development there. Therefore, a solution to eradicate America's structural racism would be to give back what was taken away at the very beginning- opportunities and amenities. Provide proper housing and adequate resources to schools where the majority of students are people of color and come from low-income families. By doing this, people could use these resources to educate themselves and achieve numerous goals that will hopefully give them a better life.

What if we create a machine learning algorithm that does this automatically for us? We can start at the education level by ensuring education centers in poor minority areas are modernized and teach a well-rounded curriculum that inspires young students to grow into the person they wish to be. To ensure education remains a top priority at these schools we can implement types of positions that ensure the safety of education atmospheres and denounce crime related activity. Once the education level plan is intact it must be monitored and consistently altered to fit the active world's society and top understanding. After this we may move onto aid. Aid must be given out to those who absolutely need it. In the aid we should implement growth incentives to ensure that the people who are receiving aid are growing and putting themselves into valuable positions in society that not only hold value to them, but society as a whole. They define redlining as "the practice of banks withholding home loan funds or Insurance from neighborhoods considered poor economic risks", and this is a very key way that racial biases and discrimination were being built into our society at a structural level because the video showed us that these real estate appraisers had clear signs of bias in their evaluations of these neighborhoods. One of the documents provided by these real estate appraisers describing the neighborhoods that were surveyed said the area is well laid out and improvements are attractive, but the proximity of negro families on Spruce St caused the score to suffer. These real estate appraisers were deliberately giving lower scores to neighborhoods that had even the slightest relations with African Americans, ultimately causing these people to have significantly worse living situations, no home loan funds or insurance, despite some of them not having any kind of economic risks to the banks. I believe that one way we can help address this problem is to not allow race to be a factor when determining the ratings of these neighborhoods, being that essentially the main reason several neighborhoods were redlined was due to the heavy concentration of minorities and more specifically negros, we can conclude that these maps should no longer be considered an accurate way of measuring the economic status of these neighborhoods, and we have to institute a re-evaluation of these neighborhoods in order to acquire more accurate results without racial bias. What if we create a machine learning algorithm that does this automatically for us? We could manually correct a large set of data, feed it into the “bias-removal” algorithm and teach it to remove biases. After that algorithm does its work, we can feed the sanitized data into the policing algorithm. This solution appears to be more cost effective than manually removing the bias in all sets of data. funding.raw_text: An influential and impactful way to address/change the fact that American society has always been historically unequal and discriminatory towards minorities, especially African Americans, is giving more opportunities to minorities. As seen in the "IP student video," one of the students explained the impacts and gravity of "Redlining" which, "... the effects of racist initiatives, such as redlining, and how it affected people to this day in regards to the funding in which their middle school or elementary school received, which oftentimes were zoned based on where they lived. Unfortunately, the quality of the education lacked in areas where people were poor, and oftentimes these areas were mostly populated with people of color or minority groups." Unfortunately, fixing the grave mistakes and damage of redlining is no easy feat, in which solutions could take decades to be implemented, however, offering more opportunities such as jobs and better education to minorities that are still impacted by the effects of redlining can allow them to have a better chance of succeeding in the United States.

show.raw_text: In the Vox video titled Vox Video titled Does My Neighborhood Determine My Future?  they mention "The first policy was called the homeowners loan corporation or HOLC or "hulk" part of HOLC was sending real estate appraisers to hundreds of cities across the country and these appraisers would grade neighbors in these cities, and this is where the term redlining comes from." They define redlining as "the practice of banks withholding home loan funds or Insurance from neighborhoods considered poor economic risks", and this is a very key way that racial biases and discrimination were being built into our society at a structural level because the video showed us that these real estate appraisers had clear signs of bias in their evaluations of these neighborhoods. One of the documents provided by these real estate appraisers describing the neighborhoods that were surveyed said the area is well laid out and improvements are attractive, but the proximity of negro families on Spruce St caused the score to suffer. At the southern edge precludes the district from a better rating, and is retarding its development. These real estate appraisers were deliberately giving lower scores to neighborhoods that had even the slightest relations with African Americans, ultimately causing these people to have significantly worse living situations, no home loan funds or insurance, despite some of them not having any kind of economic risks to the banks. I believe that one way we can help address this problem is to not allow race to be a factor when determining the ratings of these neighborhoods, being that essentially the main reason several neighborhoods were redlined was due to the heavy concentration of minorities and more specifically negros, we can conclude that these maps should no longer be considered an accurate way of measuring the economic status of these neighborhoods, and we have to institute a re-evaluation of these neighborhoods in order to acquire more accurate results without racial bias. This could involve training thousands of people to survey neighborhoods and diagnose problems to be solved.

future.raw_text: In the Vox video titled Vox Video titled Does My Neighborhood Determine My Future?  they mention "The first policy was called the homeowners loan corporation or HOLC or "hulk" part of HOLC was sending real estate appraisers to hundreds of cities across the country and these appraisers would grade neighbors in these cities, and this is where the term redlining comes from." They define redlining as "the practice of banks withholding home loan funds or Insurance from neighborhoods considered poor economic risks", and this is a very key way that racial biases and discrimination were being built into our society at a structural level because the video showed us that these real estate appraisers had clear signs of bias in their evaluations of these neighborhoods. One of the documents provided by these real estate appraisers describing the neighborhoods that were surveyed said the area is well laid out and improvements are attractive, but the proximity of negro families on Spruce St caused the score to suffer. At the southern edge precludes the district from a better rating, and is retarding its development. These real estate appraisers were deliberately giving lower scores to neighborhoods that had even the slightest relations with African Americans, ultimately causing these people to have significantly worse living situations, no home loan funds or insurance, despite some of them not having any kind of economic risks to the banks. I believe that one way we can help address this problem is to not allow race to be a factor when determining the ratings of these neighborhoods, being that essentially the main reason several neighborhoods were redlined was due to the heavy concentration of minorities and more specifically negros, we can conclude that these maps should no longer be considered an accurate way of measuring the economic status of these neighborhoods, and we have to institute a re-evaluation of these neighborhoods in order to acquire more accurate results without racial bias. This could involve training thousands of people to survey neighborhoods and diagnose problems to be solved.

Therefore, a solution to eradicate America's structural racism would be to give back what was taken away at the very beginning- opportunities and amenities. american_society.question: structure
american_society.raw_text: At a structural level racism exists due to the fact that back when cities were developing, people would not sell their property to African Americans or other minority groups. This resulted in structural racism, or geographically divided cities based on race. One way to end the racism built into American society could be by increasing opportunities to those inside of the redlined neighborhoods. This could be through something such as offering more aid for the schools to provide the students with a better quality education, creating more students in search of professional careers, which would result in a higher income that would allow them to leave or improve upon their neighborhoods. This would lessen and eventually eradicate the structural divide in the nation amongst whites and minorities, resulting in more diverse neighborhoods which would lead to less racist arrests due it being harder to target one specific neighborhood with a minority majority.

american_society.question: history

However, with activism like the Black Lives Matter movement, people can begin to recognize their flaws and change for the better. Activism helps bring awareness to more and more people, which may in time, lessen the effects of historical racism by discouraging racist ideas in those who have been touched by the movement. They define redlining as "the practice of banks withholding home loan funds or Insurance from neighborhoods considered poor economic risks", and this is a very key way that racial biases and discrimination were being built into our society at a structural level because the video showed us that these real estate appraisers had clear signs of bias in their evaluations of these neighborhoods. fund.question: structure
fund.raw_text: In the Vox video titled Vox Video titled Does My Neighborhood Determine My Future?  they mention "The first policy was called the homeowners loan corporation or HOLC or "hulk" part of HOLC was sending real estate appraisers to hundreds of cities across the country and these appraisers would grade neighbors in these cities, and this is where the term redlining comes from." They define redlining as "the practice of banks withholding home loan funds or Insurance from neighborhoods considered poor economic risks", and this is a very key way that racial biases and discrimination were being built into our society at a structural level because the video showed us that these real estate appraisers had clear signs of bias in their evaluations of these neighborhoods. One of the documents provided by these real estate appraisers describing the neighborhoods that were surveyed said the area is well laid out and improvements are attractive, but the proximity of negro families on Spruce St caused the score to suffer. At the southern edge precludes the district from a better rating, and is retarding its development. These real estate appraisers were deliberately giving lower scores to neighborhoods that had even the slightest relations with African Americans, ultimately causing these people to have significantly worse living situations, no home loan funds or insurance, despite some of them not having any kind of economic risks to the banks. I believe that one way we can help address this problem is to not allow race to be a factor when determining the ratings of these neighborhoods, being that essentially the main reason several neighborhoods were redlined was due to the heavy concentration of minorities and more specifically negros, we can conclude that these maps should no longer be considered an accurate way of measuring the economic status of these neighborhoods, and we have to institute a re-evaluation of these neighborhoods in order to acquire more accurate results without racial bias. This could involve training thousands of people to survey neighborhoods and diagnose problems to be solved.

new_data.raw_text: At present, the predictive policing service used by the police is not perfect. In my opinion, this system needs more dynamic data. I think if the police prediction system can become smarter, you can effectively reduce the conflict between the police and people of color, as you all know, the police often predict high-risk area to the patrol system, under the condition of the imperfect system prediction, usually there will be many colored people live in this area, but this does not mean that the region is at a high risk. However, the results given by the system can lead the police to think that this is a high-risk area, so there is a risk that the police will patrol with this sentiment, and people of color will feel uncomfortable because their neighborhoods are often patrolled by the police. Over time, there are bound to be conflicts and unnecessary accidents. However, with better prediction systems, police can predict risk areas more rationally, thus reducing unnecessary losses. My solution optimizes and improves the police forecasting system, enabling police to patrol better and reduce unnecessary losses. It also creates more trust in the police system, rather than fear or unease about police action. People of color also think that the police are patrolling the streets and not trying to suppress them. The analytics for high risk areas, they result in a over policing for colored and the opposite for whites. Thus there is some influence in the algorithm that derives racial profiling.

These real estate appraisers were deliberately giving lower scores to neighborhoods that had even the slightest relations with African Americans, ultimately causing these people to have significantly worse living situations, no home loan funds or insurance, despite some of them not having any kind of economic risks to the banks. I believe that one way we can help address this problem is to not allow race to be a factor when determining the ratings of these neighborhoods, being that essentially the main reason several neighborhoods were redlined was due to the heavy concentration of minorities and more specifically negros, we can conclude that these maps should no longer be considered an accurate way of measuring the economic status of these neighborhoods, and we have to institute a re-evaluation of these neighborhoods in order to acquire more accurate results without racial bias. problem.raw_text: In the Vox video titled Vox Video titled Does My Neighborhood Determine My Future?  they mention "The first policy was called the homeowners loan corporation or HOLC or "hulk" part of HOLC was sending real estate appraisers to hundreds of cities across the country and these appraisers would grade neighbors in these cities, and this is where the term redlining comes from." They define redlining as "the practice of banks withholding home loan funds or Insurance from neighborhoods considered poor economic risks", and this is a very key way that racial biases and discrimination were being built into our society at a structural level because the video showed us that these real estate appraisers had clear signs of bias in their evaluations of these neighborhoods. One of the documents provided by these real estate appraisers describing the neighborhoods that were surveyed said the area is well laid out and improvements are attractive, but the proximity of negro families on Spruce St caused the score to suffer. At the southern edge precludes the district from a better rating, and is retarding its development. These real estate appraisers were deliberately giving lower scores to neighborhoods that had even the slightest relations with African Americans, ultimately causing these people to have significantly worse living situations, no home loan funds or insurance, despite some of them not having any kind of economic risks to the banks. I believe that one way we can help address this problem is to not allow race to be a factor when determining the ratings of these neighborhoods, being that essentially the main reason several neighborhoods were redlined was due to the heavy concentration of minorities and more specifically negros, we can conclude that these maps should no longer be considered an accurate way of measuring the economic status of these neighborhoods, and we have to institute a re-evaluation of these neighborhoods in order to acquire more accurate results without racial bias. environment.question: tech
environment.raw_text: In order to work on racism in technology we would have to start by thinking about the people who create this technology. One solution is that there should be more diversity when it comes to technology. This is because with more people from different backgrounds there is a higher chance that there are not  as many biased decisions or racially motivated decisions. We would tackle any potential challenges by making sure that the environment is inclusive so that feedback and suggestions are taken seriously.

environment.raw_text: Another way to change the fact that racial biases and discrimination are built into our society at a structural level would be by building up the minority communities neighborhoods. Racial minorities tend to live in areas that do not create a environment to learn and grow as a person, if we start by building these communities up by completely revamping their education systems etc. this could help bridge the gap between education in different races.

big.question: history
big.raw_text: Racism has been a big problem and controversial issue in America for a long time. American society has been historically unequal and discriminatory, and structural racism is reproduced over time. It should not be unknown to us how people other than white complexion have been and are still being treated. We have failed as a society. Racism still exists between us and somehow reproduces over time. People believing in race superiority has been promoting their agenda. Historically America has always prefered white people over any other skin color and always violated black or brown people rights. American cops have been unrightfully arrested and accused black people with charges for the crimes they haven't even done. They created an image of black people as a negative member of their society and have always violated and discriminated against them. Now when AI technology like PredPol uses previous crime data, which was completely against black people. It targets more black people and thus in a way creating more racism.

Also, coming up with more policies that would restrict the power given to police officers. There should be more organizations or groups that study this and try to get to the macro level of racism. These groups would focus on promoting anti-racism and educating people as well as getting to the core of the problem. big.raw_text: We would change this by increasing awareness and acknowledging the structural racism that is built within American society. When there is such a long history of racism that has been built into the structure of society there must be an increase in awareness in order to progress society and its structure forward towards equality. This could be done through education and programs across the nation, in both big cities and small towns. In order to make sure the education and programs reach every American, they will be offered through both public and private schools, along with centers in every town.

african_americans.question: structure
african_americans.raw_text: In order to change the societal norm of racism I could theoretically fund a program that seeks to change the way courts prosecute minorities. The current court system rates peoples risk of doing crime again by a system in which they consider upbringing and education. This is innate racist because of how African Americans/ other minorities make less than the wealthy(mostly white 1%). By removing this rating system they can help alleviate the systematic injustice against minorities in the court.

african_americans.question: structure
african_americans.raw_text: To change the fact that "American society has been historically unequal and discriminatory, and structural racism is reproduced over time," we must dive deeper into the root of the problem. Following the abolition of slavery, African Americans were met with harsh discrimination and faced new hurdles like  Jim Crow Laws and additional systems meant to oppress black communities. Even following the desegregation of public schools through the ruling of Brown v. Board in 1954, there have been large gaps between the academic success of African-Americans and white Americans. To alter this, America's public education system should be streamlined in order to level the playing field for all students. Schools should receive equal funding, have the same curriculum, and offer easily accessible resources to students. The academic success of students drives their futures. Enhancing the education received by black communities will promote better economic/socio economic standings for black americans.

african_americans.question: structure
african_americans.raw_text: At a structural level racism exists due to the fact that back when cities were developing, people would not sell their property to African Americans or other minority groups. This resulted in structural racism, or geographically divided cities based on race. One way to end the racism built into American society could be by increasing opportunities to those inside of the redlined neighborhoods. This could be through something such as offering more aid for the schools to provide the students with a better quality education, creating more students in search of professional careers, which would result in a higher income that would allow them to leave or improve upon their neighborhoods. This would lessen and eventually eradicate the structural divide in the nation amongst whites and minorities, resulting in more diverse neighborhoods which would lead to less racist arrests due it being harder to target one specific neighborhood with a minority majority.

african_americans.question: history
african_americans.raw_text: An influential and impactful way to address/change the fact that American society has always been historically unequal and discriminatory towards minorities, especially African Americans, is giving more opportunities to minorities. As seen in the "IP student video," one of the students explained the impacts and gravity of "Redlining" which, "... the effects of racist initiatives, such as redlining, and how it affected people to this day in regards to the funding in which their middle school or elementary school received, which oftentimes were zoned based on where they lived. Unfortunately, the quality of the education lacked in areas where people were poor, and oftentimes these areas were mostly populated with people of color or minority groups." Unfortunately, fixing the grave mistakes and damage of redlining is no easy feat, in which solutions could take decades to be implemented, however, offering more opportunities such as jobs and better education to minorities that are still impacted by the effects of redlining can allow them to have a better chance of succeeding in the United States.

african_americans.question: history
african_americans.raw_text: Reallocate overfunded programs such as the police towards youth programs, housing programs, food programs to uplift communities of African Americans that were historically depressed.

african_americans.question: structure
african_americans.raw_text: In the Vox video titled Vox Video titled Does My Neighborhood Determine My Future?  they mention "The first policy was called the homeowners loan corporation or HOLC or "hulk" part of HOLC was sending real estate appraisers to hundreds of cities across the country and these appraisers would grade neighbors in these cities, and this is where the term redlining comes from." They define redlining as "the practice of banks withholding home loan funds or Insurance from neighborhoods considered poor economic risks", and this is a very key way that racial biases and discrimination were being built into our society at a structural level because the video showed us that these real estate appraisers had clear signs of bias in their evaluations of these neighborhoods. One of the documents provided by these real estate appraisers describing the neighborhoods that were surveyed said the area is well laid out and improvements are attractive, but the proximity of negro families on Spruce St caused the score to suffer. At the southern edge precludes the district from a better rating, and is retarding its development. These real estate appraisers were deliberately giving lower scores to neighborhoods that had even the slightest relations with African Americans, ultimately causing these people to have significantly worse living situations, no home loan funds or insurance, despite some of them not having any kind of economic risks to the banks. I believe that one way we can help address this problem is to not allow race to be a factor when determining the ratings of these neighborhoods, being that essentially the main reason several neighborhoods were redlined was due to the heavy concentration of minorities and more specifically negros, we can conclude that these maps should no longer be considered an accurate way of measuring the economic status of these neighborhoods, and we have to institute a re-evaluation of these neighborhoods in order to acquire more accurate results without racial bias. This could involve training thousands of people to survey neighborhoods and diagnose problems to be solved.

social_media.raw_text: The human element of racism might be the most important place to try to create change in our society. The execution of this would be to go to sources of information that people rely on the most, this would be social media, influencers, advertisements, and people that many respect such as celebrities. Then we would need to weed out the ones who are racist using some sort of test and find the most neutral ones. Then we would have to spam advertisements posts and have people sponsor messages that relate to equality and human rights. We would take experts on the topic of inequality and put them on the forefront of the movement and force people to listen to them because time and time again we have been shown that people would rather ignore a problem than face it.
